title: Ticket #7740: Port BLAHP to gcc 10
description:
So, my little fedora box got a new version of gcc, and now the BLAHP fails to compile, or link really:

gcc -g -O0 -o BLClient BLClient.o blah_utils.o BLfunctions.o -ldl -lpthread

/usr/bin/ld: BLfunctions.o:/home/gthain/condor/b/externals/bundles/blahp/1.16.5.1/blahp-prefix/src/blahp/src/BLfunctions.h:73:

multiple definition of `argv0'; BLClient.o:/home/gthain/condor/b/externals/bundles/blahp/1.16.5.1/blahp-prefix/src/blahp/src/./BLfunctions.h:73: first defined here

Hmm. gthain@gthain src]$ nm BLClient.o | grep argv0 0000000000000000 B argv0 [gthain@gthain src]$ nm BLfunctions.o | grep argv0 0000000000000000 B argv0

Well, the linker seems to have a point here -- linking together two .o's, each with a global data variable with the same name (argv0). And why did the compiler do that?

both BLClient.c and BLfunctions.c include BLfunctions.h, and in this header file, we see on line 73:

char *argv0;

no extern, no static, just a definition. And there's a bunch of other variables like this causing multiply-defined symbols, but let's ignore that for now.

So, how did this ever work, I ask myself?

Compiling this on older versions of gcc shows that older versions of gcc put these symbols in the "C"ommon block.

Turns out, there's a gcc command line option, -fcommon that controls whether global variables with "tentative definitions" are put into the Common block (-fcommon) or put into the BSS (-fno-common). And, the default from time immemorial was -fcommon, but gcc 10 changed this to -fno-common, without much fanfare.

Note this is one of these oddball corners where C is different than C++: the c++ language definition says these can't go in the common block, and must create multiply defined symbols, and the blahp is written in C, not C++.

So, the immediate fix is to add -fcommon to the command line, but in the long term we should extern these in the header file and define them in a c file.
